Park Task Force
Reports to Mayor
by Frank Capri°
The preliminary results of the
investigation by the Wyman
Park Task Force into the fate
of the park were presented to
Mayor Donald Schaefer and
the head of the Parks Board in
a private meeting Tuesday morning at City Hall.
The task force was formed as
a result of last summer's request by the University to ob
tam n Wyman Park as a site for
construction of new research
facilities designed to attract
prestigious scientific organizations and foundations to the
Homewood campus. Thy

University argued that these affiliations would broaden the
scope of Hopkins while bringing new jobs to the city. The
plan to turn over the park,
however, met with strong community reaction.
The task force's interim
report, which was based on the
findings of several separate
meetings with community
leaders and university officials,
outlined a proposal which
would allow Hopkins to expand
its facilities at Homewood,
while keeping the park intact.
The recommendations were

Registrar's New Report Finds
Enrollment on the Upswing
by Jeff Horn
The Hopkins community is
growing and changing according to the results of a recent
registrar's report which
documents 1985 fall term
enrollment.
The report shows that the
Homewood campus' enrollment has grown from 1,812
undergraduates in the School of
Arts and Sciences in 1984 to
1,861 in 1985. The G.W.C.
Whiting School of Engineering
has also grown from 566
undergruaduates last year to
604 this year.
The rest of the Hopkins community however, is stagnant
relative to Homewood—with
the only growth outside Homewood coming from the admission of more special students
and the addition of the nursing
program.

The Hopkins community totals 11,656 students this year as
opposed to 11,136 last year.
This total includes Homewood,
the Medical School, Public
Health, Nursing, The School of
Advanced International Studies
(SAIS) in Washington D.C.,
SAIS' campus in Bologna, Italy, and the Peabody Conservatory.
The enrollment at the
Homewood campus is 9,066,
up from 8,628 last year. The increase comes from many more
part-time graduate students in
more
and
engineering
undergrad special students in
the School of Continuing
Studies.
There are 2,660 full time
undergraduates and graduates
in the School of Arts and
Sciences, 856 full-time
engineering undergraduates and
graduates, 2,287 part-time

engineering undergraduates and
graduates and 3,263 undergraduates and graduates in the
School of Continuing Studies.
The other reports from the
registrar show the other
changes in the demographics of
the Homewood campus, like
sex, major, and hometown.
Women, for example, are 34.2
percent of all undergraduates.
In Arts and Sciences, women
are 38.3 percent of the undergraduates, as compared to only 21.1 percent in Engineering.
The report also broke down
enrollment by major at
Homewood. Natural Science
Majors (all sciences) constitute
34.1 percent with biology,
chemistry, and natural science
area majors or declared premeds making up 27.2 percent of
the undergraduates.

All Factions Pleased With
Task Force's Park Report
Continued from Page 1

presented to the press by David
S. Cordish, the lawyer who
headed the task force. "By consensus, the park will remain a
park," he explained, "Yet part
of Wyman will be made
available to the University on a
lease basis for use by intramural
athletics."
This, in turn, would allow
the university-owned BIA field,
which is currently located in a
ravine on the western side of
San Martin Drive, to be used as
a development site for further
expansion. Hopkins would then
be permitted to lease the section
of Wyman Park known as
"The Meadow" to use as the
new intramural field.
"The concept of putting the
intramural field in the park is
enthusiastically supported by
the entire task force, including
neighborhood leaders, city
liasons, and Hopkins," stated
Cordish. "The task force had
to assimilate different needs, all
of which were very legitimate
and very understandable.
"The park is a wonderful
treasure. We feel that if it could
possibly be preserved, that
would be a tremendous plus,"
Cordish continued. "But allowing Hopkins to expand would
also be of tremendous social
good. The solution was a
natural outcome [which was]
the result of the hearings and
testimonies we had."
Ross Jones, university vicepresident and secretary, and
representative on the task force
stated that the school wholeheartedly endorses the plan.
"This proposal accomplishes
three things: It gives Hopkins
more
opportunity
to
develop.. .grants us the oppor-

tunity to acquire much needed
space, and allows the community to preserve open vistas,"
summarized Jones.
Dagman Miller, chairperson
of the Commitee United to
Save Wyman Park, said she
was "optimistic and thankful"
and looked upon the proposal
with "much enthusiasm.""We
as neighbors were reacting to
something we felt strongly
about," she said. "Our park is
precious." Miller expressed her
satisfaction at being "part of
the process" in determining the
park's fate and looked forward
to "continued efforts to save
parkland."
Mayor Shaefer was extremely pleased with the interim
report findings and recommendation. "I knew what the
answer would be—there would
be no compromise of the city's
parkland. The proposal is a
wonderful concept," he said.
Schaefer commended all involved for "their leadership"
and was amazed at the level of
cooperation that led to the
resolution. "The amount of erroneous information out there
this summer was amazing to
me. Now Hopkins and the
community are talking and
that's how the situation got
worked out. I just can't get
over my admiration."
Schaefer strongly defended
the solution recommended by
the task force after it was
criticized as only "a stopgap"
which did not consider the
long-term problem. The future
need for university expansion
will have to be dealt with as it
arises in the future, explained
the mayor. He also argued that
the great aspect of the present
proposal is that its acceptable
by everyone.

"Not only does it preserve
the park but it generates jobs
that are very important," he explained."We have to realize the
importance of the relationship
of a university and its
community."
The mayor formed the task
last summer in response to outcries not only from community resdents, but from individuals from all over
Maryland and the nation. Concerns about saving parkland
came from as far away as
California according to the
thayor.
"Parks belong to everyone,"
said the mayor. "There's a lot
of work still to do, but to me,
[the major conflict] is solved.
The details of the recommendation are yet to be worked out.
The problem of exactly where
and how much acerage would
become available to Hopkins
must still be decided. The
technical aspects of the lease
agreement will also have to be
discussed, as well as the question of who will be responsible
to maintain the parkland.
Cordish did make it clear,
however, that only the land the
University requires for the
athletic field will be leased. The
area will not be cleared but instead is to be used in its current
state. Residents feel that this
agreement will not cause any
problems since many students
and student groups already use
the park for athletic purposes.
The task force is scheduled to
present its final report to the
mayor on December 1.
Although the final decision
rests with the Parks Board, the
unanimous support of the proposal by the mayor and the task
force should guarantee its
approval.

Maiden McShuttle
Run Begins Today
"It'll beat ARA," or so says
Dave Shade co-chairman of the
Student Services Committee
which has slated the first run of
the Homewood "McShuttle"
for this evening. The shuttle
which will run continuously
from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. today
and every Friday will take off
from M.S.E. and drop students
off at the McDonalds on York
Road.
According to Shade, the idea
for the service was conceived
last year by the committee,
"but it didn't really get off the
ground." This year the Student

Services Committee definitively decided to set up the van service and model it after the
University of Maryland's
"McShuttle" which, according
to Shade, is a big success at that
campus.
Describing the new shuttle,
Shade said,"We don't want to
get stuck to a specific schedule,
but a student won't have to
wait more than fifteen minutes
to catch a ride up."
The new "McShuttle" is
sponsored jointly by the Student Services Committee and
the Office of Student Activities.

The fifth annual Phi Psi 500
was held throughout the afternoon of Saturday, October 26,
on the Gilman Quad. The Phi
Psi 500 is a competition sponsored each year by the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity with the proceeds from entry fees going
directly to Santa Claus
Anonymous, a Baltimore charity which to help area needy
around Christmas time.
The winning teams in the
competition were the Pink
Flamingos, HYC, Radioactive
Bat Jiz, Beasts of Baker,
Drunk, and Slick and His
Heads. Kegs were awarded to
the Alpha Phi and Phi Mu
Sororities, Phi Kappa Psi Little Sisters, and the Pi Lambda
Phi fraternity. Phi Kappa Psi
collected close to 1200 dollars
for Santa Claus Anonymous. A
total of 225 students participated in the games.
In the past, the Phi Psi 500

race had been a 1.5-mile run
and beer drinking contest, but
the fraternity had to change to
the present format last year, in
view of the revised administration policy on student drinking
on campus and at university
events.
This year's competition was
organized by race chairmen
Srikar Reddy and Sanjiv Patel.
Students formed teams of
five people and, for a four
dollar donation per participant,
they were permitted, even encouraged, to compete in a
variety of challenging events.
Dinners at Armand's Pizzeria
were presented to the top six
teams, kegs were awarded, and
all participants recieved Phi Psi
500 T-Shirts, free sodas, and invitations to the "500 Party" at
the fraternity house Saturday
night. A disc jockey was on
hand to play records during the
games, and a local radio station
gave out free prizes.

The Henry Luce Foundation
annually selects 15 Luce
Scholars from a variety of
backgrounds to spend a year
in the Far East. The program
built around individual internships and work/study arrangements developed by
representatives of the Asia
Foundation and based on the
student's career interest and
preparation. The scholarship
award includes a substantial
stipend plus a family and
transportation allowance.
Rather than offer training
for future Asian specialists, this
program concentrates exclusively on providing an intensive experience in Asia to
young Americans from other
fields who would not otherwise expect to have such an
opportunity during the normal course of their career.
This program involves no
academic credit, and the participants normally do not
enroll in academic institutions. Luce Scholars have interned in the past with an architectural firm in Tokyo, a
forestry project in Indonesia,
a training facility for public
administration in Malaysia, a
master gardener in Kyoto, a
community medicine project
in the Philippines, and a
in

Churchill Scholarships are
awarded for either a one or
three-year program of study
in engineering, mathematics,
or the natural sciences at
Churchill College, Cambridge University, England.
Applicants must be U.S.
citizens currently enrolled at
Hopkins who will hold a
bachelor's degree and be
under twenty-six years of age
by October 1 of the academic
year for which they are applying. Candidates may not
have attained a doctorate.
Hopkins nominates two
students annually. From the
nominees of all participating
colleges and universities, the
Foundation
Churchill
chooses approximately ten
Churchill Scholars each year.
Selection is highly competitive and based on
academic
outstanding
achievement, scores on the
Graduate Record Examination, demonstrated concern
for critical problems of society, and capacity for original
and creative work. Applicants must take both the
Aptitude and the Advance
Tests on or before the October GRE test date and have
the scores sent directly to the
Churchill Foundation.

by Eileen Duffy
Last Friday visiting Electrical
Engineering Professor Daniel
Slotnick died after running at
the Homewood Field track.
Slotnick had just finished
running when he fell to the
ground and started convulsing.
Senior Clark Theilemann, who
was at the track, ran to get
trainer Nancy Fassio Groves.
"I saw him walk off the track
and then he fell down so I ran
in and got the trainer,"
Theilemann said.
Groves then began administering CPR while an ambulance was called. Groves asked for help and was aided by
Senior Eileen Janec.
"This was the first time that
I had to give CPR, and I'm
glad that there was someone to
help me, this is when you
realize how important knowing
CPR is," Groves said.
The ambulance came and
Slotnick was taken to Union
Memorial and died around 6:00
p.m. of a heart attack. He was
53 years old.

Is Everybody Happy?
If journalists are, as somebody once
said, professional complainers, then the
Wyman Park deal announced this week
is a journalist's nightmare. Nobody
seems to be upset.
We have to admit that's actually a
good thing, of course. The mayor's task
force, composed of university representatives and community members, has apparently found a fair and reasonable
solution that everyone can live with.
Although the details are still undecided, the basic idea is that the university
will lease part of the park to use as an
intramural field, allowing it to build on
the current intramural field, which the
university owns. (The part of the park
to be leased is near the intersection of
Tudor Arms Avenue and University
Parkway.)
Since an athletic field will disrupt the
park far less than a new research
building, the save-the-park forces are
happy. Since Hopkins will have far more
land to build on than it previously did,
the university is happy.
In the midst of all the celebrating,
however, it ought to be remembered—

as we noted a few weeks ago—that the
whole fuss really need never have arisen.
Somebody within the university could
certainly have thought of a solution like
this one before the school tried to take
over the park in the first place. Instead,
the university tried to grab the land during the summer (which looked sneaky),
and the university's relationship with the
community—which has never been very
good—worsened considerably.
When the brouhaha reached its
zenith—and when both sides began looking to him for support—the mayor
organized the task force which has just
recommended the compromise described above. And while both sides actually
involved in the dispute seem to be fairly
happy, it is the mayor, of course, who
comes off smelling the most like a rose.
The university can hardly be said to
have won this one. It got into an unnecessary squabble with a community
that already didn't like it very much. But
neither did it lose, and maybe, considering the way the whole affair began, that
was the best that could be expected.

An Offensive Article

To the Editor:
Frank Caprio
I respect good comedy and
good jokes and like to think
that I can take them in stride
But I do not find Sujata Banarjee's "Where the Boys Are:
Searching for Waves at JHU"
to be good comedy or even to
contain good jokes. In fact, I
found the article to be degrading, humiliating, and offensive.
I found particularly offensive
the part on New Jersey. Being
a resident of N.J. has nothing
to do with this at all. . .well
maybe not, but it makes no
difference.
Miss Banerjee jests about
there existing Bar Mitzvahs in
N.J. Although I am not an expert on Jewish affairs, I am not
naive, simple-minded or insipient enough to think that Bar
Mitzvahs do not exist outside of
N.J. I also fail to see what is so
wrong about the existence of
Bar Mitzvahs. I hope that Miss
Banerjee will explain this to me
at the next Jewish Association
meeting.
I have never made any pretenses that I come from New
York, and I do not think that
I have a nasal-pitched accent.
Therefore these two statements
about all N.J. JHU students are
lies.
I would like to commend
Miss Banerjee on writing an offensive and misleading article
and would hope that she finds
it in her heart not to continue
these types of jests.
Ty Hyderally

To the Editor:
In a letter to the editor (Oct. 18)
Kathleen Scogna wrote an opposition to Joe Chen's "A
Report on the Women's
Report." Unlike Chen, Scogna
supports affirmative action as
a hiring practice.
Scogna is concerned that oppressed groups have more
obstacles in their way of achieving success than others. She is
not concerned, however, that
while trying to undo the
damage that has been done to
minorities, innocent members
of the "majority" will be hurt.
Because she wants society to
practice more humanitarian
values, Scogna supports a hiring practice which is as damaging and morally repugnant as
that to which she is opposed.
Minority members may now
be getting jobs which they
would not have gotten before,
but they are not learning the
skills necessary for obtaining
and keeping these jobs should
affirmative action be repealed.
Employers, meanwhile, are
forced to maintain quotas, a
practice which limits their ability to hire the best applicants
and inevitably results in a less
productive society. Finally, affirmative action is, by definition, discriminatory. The focus
of discrimination has merely
been shifted.
Given these detriments, it is
hard to understand why
anyone, especially someone
who espouses humanitarianism, can advocate affirmative
action. The only hiring practice
which is morally defensible is
one which is based solely on
merit.
Debra Hamel

Looking at the Sky
To the Editor:
I would like to thank Donna
Peremes for giving me this
chance to further lash out at her
and all of the other members of
the Feminist Alliance who objected to the "advice" I gave in

my book review of Dr. Fegg's
Encyclopaedia of All World
Knowledge. My response will
be two-fold. The first as
generic, cliche and technical as
the Peremes letter, and the second completely different.
Now, the generic one. Leaving aside the inherent hypocrisy
of "resenting advice" and the
inanity of voicing "objections
[which] are fairly apparent,"
the first question I would like
to address is whether a comparison of the Feminist Alliance
and the American Nazi Party is
patently absurd."
It would depend on the nature of the comparison, would
it not? If they are grouped
together under the heading
"organizations" clearly it is not
absurd, whereas under the
heading "White Supremacy
Groups" it would be. The
heading used was "extremist
group," and "extremist being
a subjective appraisal which to
me means advocating an act
which / believe to be ludicrous,
I am perfectly within my right
to compare these two groups.
This is because I believe both
extermination of Jews and
TEP-newsletter banning to be
ludicrous. If the Alliance is insulted, good—perhaps it will
make them rethink their past
actions. I must stress that I
mean no insult to females as a
whole, just as I mean no insult
to whites as a whole (indeed,
some of my best friends are
white and/or female).
Now the humour issue—Peremes comes so close when she
points out that Pythons'
remarks are "many times...a
mockery." They never mean to
insult, if they do, it's because
you choose to be insulted, and
is that any fault of theirs, much
less grounds for censorship?
Of course there is blatant
misogyny and racism in our
society, but not in Python.
Python is art, and art has no
room for malice. Art is presented to be interpreted, and that
interpretation should be left to
the interpreter—not to myself,
the Feminist Alliance, or any

third party.
Indeed, I am not advocating
that we "park our brains outside the theater door," but I am
advocating taking our brains
out of reverse and realizing that
interpretation of art has no
ablsoute truth, and so a critique
should be taken for what it is—
a subjective statement of one
person's truth, in this case my
truth, which is that ragging on
feminists is funny. This is no
more or less true than Peremes's
assertion that it is not—but
neither of us has a right to force
our opinions on any third party, which is what Peremes and
the truly malicious misogynist
such as the rapist both do.
Why then, do I critique and
give advice? Simple, it's fun,
and I get free books. Anyone is
free to throw my opinions
away. No one is free to cross
Peremes's own "line" between
humour and sexism. Take your
pick of critics.
And now for something completely different: Listen, Donna, yeah, you were supposed to
"chuckle it off." If more people were less uptight and just
took the time to relax, look at
the sky and love each other,
there would be no reason for
any of these bad feelings. I love
you, Donna. So do my roommates (and the Black & Blue
Jay). Let's get together and
look at the sky sometime.
Amitava 7 Biswas A.O.

Affirmative Action II
To the Editor:
Kathleen Scogna's letter (October 18) was based on one
good idea. Jobs should be
awarded on productive ability
and passed performance not on
gender. Rational people would
judge a person on these two
criteria and expect to be judged similarly. Kathleen is angry
(justifiably so) because as she
claims these factors were not
used in the past to decide who
got a job. She says that an ad-

ministrative directive(program)
is needed to correct these past
injustices.
The program would equalize
the ratio between male and female employees at the University. The question to be asked
is "At whose expense will this
equalization be achieved?"
(Hint: think tuition.) I do not
expect the school to fire enough
male employees to achieve this
ratio. Another alternative is hiring enough women so that this
ratio is achieved right away.
Who would pay for these extra
employees?
The only "reasonable" solution is to make sure the next
people that Johns Hopkins
hires are female. Is Kathleen
asking that a job qualification
be based on gender? Isn't that
the injustice responsible for this
mess? Do not tell me that this
new injustice would correct a
past wrong. I know two wrongs
do not make a right.
The most evil part of her letter can be found in the last
paragraph. I quote,"She has to
prove herself better than all the
men competing for the same
job. Chen apparently sees
nothing wrong with this. I certainly do." Kathleen thinks it is
wrong for the University to
choose the person who is better
qualified for a job. Would
anyone have Hopkins hire the
person that is not the best for
the job? Would she still object
to that quote if two words were
added so it reads as follows?
"She has to prove herself better than all the men and women
competing for the same job."
I'm paying this University and
I expect the administration to
hire the best qualified person
for the job. Not the best qualified person of any one pressure
group. Any policy that forces
the administration to settle for
second best is wrong. I hope
Hopkins continues awarding
jobs to people who deserve
them because they worked hard
and can prove they are the best
qualified.
Jordan Levy

Hopkins Symphony's Season Begins Sunday
by Peter Oehlkers
All right, everyone raise your
hands. How many of you have
heard of the "Hopkins Symphony Orchestra?" No, not the
Peabody Orchestra. No, not the
Hopkins Band. The Hopkins
Symphony Orchestra. Yes?
Well, you're one of the few.
No? Well, don't feel bad,
neither did I. The point is, now
you have heard of them. Now
you have no excuse not to attend their Sunday afternoon
concert, an event billed as a
"Performance of Viennese
Classics," right? Enough of the
patronizing tone...
The Hopkins Symphony has
only been around for four

Let's All Go to the H.O.P.
by Kathleen McCarthy
The
HOP
(Hopkins
Organization for Programming), which was created last
year as a standing committee of
the Student Council in order to
coordinate social programming
on campus, acquired a new
director last month,junior Andrew Chun, in the wake of
Kristen Noyes's resignation
from the post. I spoke with Andrew Chun about the HOP
itself; its purpose and his plans
for the present school year.
The HOP, perhaps in no
small amount due to its relative
newness and to its unique and
somewhat misleading acronym,
generates questions from the
student body as to its actual
purpose: "Basically the HOP is
an expansion of the old social
committee of the Student Council," explains Chun. It is a
revamped social committee
with significant authority and
was formed primarily with the
idealistic purpose of hoping to
offset the impact of a "dry
campus" on Student Council
sponsored events. The advent
of a dry campus was recognized by both administrators and
students alike as having a
significant effect on the attendance of and enjoyment of
these events. "The administration and students involved,
wanted to create a new social
entity," continued Chun,
"which was primarily concerned with planning—you don't
want three big social events on
one weekend and none on the
next—and upgrading the level
of entertainment. We can no
longer get a DJ and throw
things together and call it a
dance and expect it to be successful...we have to make it a

situation where the person is
coming for the entertainment,
for the social thing we can offer you." A new organization
was called for. What Johns
Hopkins needed, apparently,
was a controlling body, with
authority, that could efficiently channel and direct social
energy into actual events. That
met need is the essence of the
HOP's existence.
Andrew Chun, as director of
that social entity, has a great
deal of responsibility. Chun
took over the position temporarily in late September, as
the executive members of the
Student Council searched for a
new director. Chun was soon
after installed officially as it
became evident that his
capabilities, zeal and previous
social committee experience
more than qualified him for the
position. Andrew Chun presides over the Executive Board
of the HOP, which consists of
representatives from the
various groups that plan social
events, i.e., The Office of
Residential Life, IFC, the Student Council, etc. The HOP
itself is further broken down into committees, in which the actual work is done: the social
committee, which plans social
events such as dances and parties; the Fine Arts Committee,
which sponsors such things as
trips to museums and plays; the
Union Board, which basically
handles any social event not
falling under the above
categories; and finally, the
Publicity Committee.
Chun sees his position as
primarily that of a coordinator,
who delegates authority, organizes the various groups and
manages the budget. He hopes

to see the position of director
evolve to this overseer role from
the role of active participant in
all the subcommittees, which
characterized the position in its
initial year. "The committees,
once started, know what to
do...my job is to approve
what they do because I'm in
touch with what everyone else
is doing. Cooperation is the
biggest thing, to get as many
groups as possible involved in
the programs...it's for the
school," says Chun.
So far the efforts of the HOP
have been encouraging. In particular, events sponsored by the
Fine Arts committee, such as
the recent A Night at the Iguana
trip, which was sold out.
The HOP is planning a big
dance on November 8 in the
Glass
Pavilion.
Chun
is
also
working
on
instituting a schoolwide semiformal in the spring. Other projects in the works are the continuation of the Comedy Clubs,
started last year, and the initiation of Coffeehouses, which
will provide a club atmosphere
in a non-alcoholic setting with
some combination of entertainment. Additionally, the Fine
Arts committee and the Union
Board continually sponsor
events. A significant key to the
success of these events is
organized publicity and good
planning. If organized sociality does improve at Johns
Hopkins, the efforts of Chun
and his committees must take
some credit. To conclude in the
words of Andrew Chun:, "I
have a lot of confidence in my
chairmen and in my committees...the HOP is doing really
well and is looking forward to
another great year."

Another development this
season is the support that has
been given to the orchestra by
the Hopkins administration, in
particular Dean Robert Welch.
According to Overhauser, in the
past there has always been "administrative tolerance" towards
the orchestra but this is the first
year there has been actual support. Another development is
the fact that the orchestra is
charging admission for the first
time (although not to Hopkins
students) which signals a real
advance in the status of the
orchestra.
This is all a great stride from

the orchestra's beginnings. It
developed out of an old S.A.C.
group called "the Chamber
Music Society," a group which
Overhauser
characterizes
as a fly-by-night group that
gave irregular performances in
the Garrett Room. When that
group met its timely end, she
went to the adminstration to get
funding for a real orchestra
(after being refused by the Student
Council).
And
so
the
Hopkins Symphony Orchestra
was born. The budget is now
three times what it once was.
Less than half of its funds come
from JHU. however, with most
coming from competitive
grants and contributions. It is
clearly coming into its own as
an orchestra of merit.

citizens, and free to Hopkins
students with 1.D. For further
information about Sunday's
concert call 338-8766 and for
information about joining the
group call 358-5254.

A quick run-down of the
essentials: The play is about a
black family living in Chicago
during the fifties. Three generations live in one apartment—
Mama (Oneeka Williams), her
35-year-old son Walter Lee
(Julian Procope), his wife Ruth
(Jacqueline Wilson), their son
Travis (Darrell Frazier), and
Walter's sister Beneatha
(Emelia Duaway). Mama receives $10,000 from her late
husband's insurance policy.
With $3500 of it she puts a
down-payment on a house that
happens to be in a white
neighborhood. The rest she
gives to Walter Lee to open a
liquor store with the condition
that he save some for
Beneatha's college education.

money. Walter then decides to
take the bribe the white
neighborhood committee has
offered them if they don't move
into the house, but he re-

The play was rather well
done, with uniformly good acting throughout. Especially
good were Jacqueline Wilson
and Oneeka Williams. Certain
scenes were very powerful. For
example, the scene in which
Ruth has to tell Walter she's
pregnant and has put down
money for an abortion.
If there was a problem with
the whole production (at least
Saturday night) it was the
mystifying audience reaction—
they seemed to think the play
was a comedy. For example,
when Mama learns Walter has
lost all the money, she loses
control and starts hitting him.
The people sitting in back of me
thought it was the funniest
thing in the world. I personally
think the cast pulled the powerful scenes off—but even during
the last scene when Walter is
struggling to hold back his
tears, telling his family how
proud he is, people in the audience were still laughing at
Darrell Frazier's imitation of a
little kid. I don't know. It may
be that in the 25 years or so
since this play was written, the
issues have gotten so cliched
that no one can take them with
complete seriousness.
Saturday night: Coffee House
in the Great Hall
I must admit that I wasn't at
the Coffee House long enough
to see all the acts but I think I
was there long enough to get a
feel for what was going on.
Unlike past coffee houses
where there has always been a
paid (semi-) professional band
or entertainer, last Saturday
night all the entertainment was
supplied by students. There
were seven acts in all, ranging
from a clarinet-flute duet to a
mime and juggling act.
This event, even more than
the other two, symbolizes what
I meant about rough edges.
None of the performances I saw
was extremely polished or
perfected—this was no talent
show—and that's good. You
don't come into the place with
great expectations all ready to
judge what's going to be put in
front of you. You marvel instead at moments which transcend the amateurish such as
singer-guitarist Jay Harris hitting an unwavering high note or
stand-up comedian Loren Fox
telling a genuinely funny joke.
That's not to say that the artists in general last weekend
weren't talented—it's just a different kind of talent—a talent
born not of polished genius but
of pleasure in performing. No
one forced anyone to play in
the Hopkins Band; no one forced anyone to act in A Raisin in
the Sun; no one forced anyone
to perform at the Coffee
House—they did what they did
because they enjoyed it. At
Hopkins, this land of work-aholics and over-achievers, that
attitude, displayed last
weekend, was unbelieveably
refreshing.

Contrary to common belief,
watching sailboats race is not
about as exciting as watching
the grass grow. One look at The
Sailor's Edge, a collection of
marine photographs by Daniel
Forster (with text by Jay
Broze), should convince even
the most cynical that there is
much more to sailing than
wearing topsiders while drinking a seabreeze at the Bar Harbour Yacht Club. The book is
a delight for world class sailor
and land-lubber alike.
The book is comprised of
four chapters, each dealing with
a specific genre of sailing. Each
chapter has a short (3 pgs.) introduction written by Broze
which informs the reader of
just what and at whom he is
looking at. These introductions
also provide a little insight into
the history and lore of these
various aspects of sailing. To
those familiar to the world of
sailing, these introductions
serve little more than to refresh
the memory. However, to the
uninitiated, they do provide
enough information to bring a
little drama to the photograph,
especially in the chapter which
deals with the Olympics.
The first chapter is entitled
"Acrobatic," as one might
guess, it deals with windsurfing,
with special attention paid to
wave-jumping. This is without
a clout:4 the most exciting part
of the book; windsurfing,
especially wave-jumping, is at
the very cutting edge of sailing
technology. The pictures are
quite powerful and visually

vibrant, expressing a wide
variety of emotions. There are
stark photographs where the
subject is not so much the windsurfer, but really the surrounding. These photos truly give the
impression of man working his
board to master the elements,
a pursuit that is both lonely and
exuberant. There are also those
pictures which are aweinspiring in the excitement and
motion that they express. These
are images that do not merely
impress; they tantalize. Upon
each viewing of this section, 1
fantasize of dropping the
books, and taking a short
board out to Kaui, or some
other land blessed with waves,
and mastering this beautiful
form of flying.
chapter,
second
The
"Athletics," deals with the
Olympics classes. Since there
are seven Olympic classes, each
form is given only a cursory
review. This is not to say that
this section was poorly done,
though. Many of the
photographs are excellent,
especially those of the Tornadoes (19 foot catamarans),
which give a marvelous impression of speed and elan. For
those in the Hopkins Sailing
Club, special attention should
be paid to the 470 section
(Hopkins owns six of these
high performance dinghies).
"Powerful," the third
chapter, focuses on the ocean
racing circuit. The photos range
from fleet pictures, which gives
the reader some idea of the immense competition, to detailed
close-ups, hectic moments of
teamwork that the rigors of
ocean racing require. There is
one fantastic sequence of
photos of the yacht Formidable
experiencing a knock-down

broach (that's big-boat talk for
tipping over, a somewhat hairy
exercise in a forty-foot yacht).
Again, the theme of man battling nature re-appears, and in
many of the photos the envious
could easily be the subject.
Maxi-boats and Twelve
Meters are the subject of the
final chapter, "Prestigious."
Maxi-boats (referring to their
racing rating, i.e. maximum
rating) are the penultimate
ocean racers, often reaching
over 80 feet in length. These
boats truly dwarf their crews,
which often number over 20
members. One step above the
maxis on the prestige scale are
the Twelve Meters. These
thoroughbreeds of the yachting
world have been exclusively used,
until recently, for America's
Cup competition. This section
is nicely executed, conferring
well a sense of the immense
power and forces that these
yachts are able to generate.
There is also a small section on
the 128 foot J-Class yacht
Velsheda. The J-Class boats
were the predecessors of the
Twelve Meters in America's
Cup competition. Velsheda is
the only surviving example of
this class that flourished in the
1930's and then quickly died
out with the advent of World
War II.
There is a small section at the
end of the book which deals
with the 1987 America's Cup,
to be held in Perth, Australia.
There are no revelations here,
the thrust being that the Twelve
Meter class, especially with its
new world champion ship, is an
extremely active class. Perth
promises to hold a great deal of
racing excitement. There is also
a section in which world-class
sailors (Bobby Naish, Dennis

Conner, Gary Jobson, and
Cino Ricci) pay homage to the
photographic genius of Daniel
Forster; high praise indeed,
coming from such revered
sailors. There is also a black
and white index of photos,
which provides interesting in-,
formation on each picture.
This is a marvelous book;
however, genius has its cost. In
this case, is is $35.00, and it will
go up to $50.00 by the end of
the year. If you are a sailing

fanatic, this book is a "mustbuy;" remember, though, that
it is a coffee table book, and is
best appreciated when shared
with friends. For many, the
price is too steep, but for those
who appreciate excellent
photography of some of the
world's most beautiful boats,
the price may just be worth it.
Definitely take a look at this
book if you get the
opportunity.

CHINESE DEMOCRACY
An investigation into the nature and
meaning of "democracy" in China today
With a report on the remarkable
but short-lived Democracy Movement

by Andrew J. Nathan

_by Howell Sasser
Chinese Democracy
by Andrew J. Nathan, Borzoi
Books, $22.95. 255 pages.
To document the history of
as broad a concept as democracy
in any nation would seem to be
a task worthy either of a
lifetime of study or of a junior
high school civics paper. It is
impossible, one would reason,
to seriously address such a subject without falling prey to
either excessive detail or excessive simplification. Chinese
Democracy manages to avoid
these traps and conveys author
Andrew J. Nathan's understanding of the subject without
useless esoterica.
Active democratic thought in
China dates only from the late
nineteenth century and dates its
birth to the demonstrations
staged by holders of official
scholarship degrees, against the
terms of the 1895 SinoJapanese peace treaty. The
scholars invoked the ancient
right of remonstrance(personal
opinions submitted to the
emperor through channels)
conferred upon the learned.

Out of these protests grew
"study societies" and political
journals circulated as private
correspondence.
These outlets of ideas were
also employed by the factions
of the so-called Democratic
Movement in the late 1970's.
Mimeographed periodicals appeared at the same time as the
"Democracy Wall," publicized
in the Western media. The factions were allowed relative
freedom of speech in as much
as none criticized the basis of
the state or the place of the
Communist Party within the
state.
These restrictions lead to a
discussion of the origins and
bases of the Chinese notion of
democracy. One of the leaders
of the nineteenth century
scholars' movement, the
political scientist Liang
Quichao, wrote that democracy
was the harmony of wills of the
individual and the state. He left
no room for possible disagreement between the tw3, and consequently, no mechanism for
dealing with dissent(other than
punitive action) was included in
any of the "democratic" con-

This is not just
another dry slog
through a dry
topic....
stitutions of the People's
Republic.
Chinese Democracy treats its
subject matter thoroughly, if
not impartially. Nathan is
openly sympathetic to the
Democratic Movement without
treating the government with
undue harshness. His extensive
use of sources and contacts
within China precludes the
sugesstion that he is a foreigner
writing solely from a
foreigner's perspective.
This is not just another dry
slog through a dry topic.
Beyond its imposing title,
Chinese Democracy presents a
lively picture of Chinese
political life and culture. It is
not just for students of political
science, but is also worthwhile
for anyone with an interest in
the world's most populous
country.

Hopkins Grad Student Astounds and Amazes
The Mental Feats ofthis "Calculating Prodigy"are Studied
by Edmund Meade
The book is The Great Mental
Calculators—Past and Present
by Steven Smith. The person is
Arthur Benjamin, a graduate
student in the mathematical
sciences department here at
Johns Hopkins. Benjamin is
the only living American whose
biography is in The Great Mental Calculators. Benjamin is not
a mathematical prodigy, but he
can multiply two three-digit
numbers together faster than an
electronic hand-held calculator.
He can even "square" a four
digit number faster than a
calculator. Numbers with a
greater number of digits take
him more time than a calculator. But he can still compute, in
his head, the value of 1521 x
7056(which equals 10,732,176)
in a matter of about 1 minute.
Right now he can comfortably
handle the "squaring" of fivedigit numbers (such as 27,354).
A worst-case scenario is the
multiplication of two different
six digit numbers by each other.
That problem will take him
several minutes.
Art Benjamin's talent puts
him into some pretty exclusive
company. He may not be a
math prodigy, but he is a
"calculating prodigy." He can
multiply, divide, square, and
find the roots of fairly large
numbers. Another calculating
prodigy that Benjamin has met,
in Amsterdam, was competely
obsessed with numbers. Benjamin, however, is interested in a
number of other things. He is
presently studying integer pro-

gramming, a facet of operations research, and discrete
mathematics.
Art Benjamin was an applied
mathematics major as an
undergraduate at CarnegieMellon University in Pittsburgh. He came to Hopkins
looking for a department that
had a fairly theoretical approach to the solution of problems in applied mathematics.
Benjamin is studying these
theoretical aspects to solve real
applied math problems.
Part of Benjamin's motivation
for practicing and reinforcing his
strength in manipulating
numbers came from his nightclub act where he performed his
math wizardry and some
displays of prestidigitation.
These and other instances in
which he interacted with the
public encouraged him to spend
the time necessary to gain great
proficiency. Thus he sometimes
feels it to be a personal
challenge to see how far he can
de‘elop his talents. When Benjamin finds himself bored while
driving, he will multiply the
numbers on license plates
together.
The methods that Benjamin
uses to achieve his mathematical manipulation are intriguing
to those interested in determining how the mind handles such
processing. When Benjamin
was an undergraduate at
Carnegie-Mellon he was introduced to Dr. William Chase,
a professor of psychology. Professor Chase sought to produce
a better programming method
for computers and new ways to

teach math. Chase examined
how Benjamin performed his
"mental feats." A problem in
this analysis was that these feats
were often performed very
quickly (the square of a three
digit number takes about a second). Chase challenged him to
perform more difficult calculations. Benjamin had to practice
but he also had to develop the
confidence that he coud do difficult manipulations. The key is
that all these numbers must be
remembered and manipulated
in the short-term memory portion of the brain.
With the manipulation taking longer, Professor Chase
could ask Benjamin questions
so that he could glean information about some of the basic
problems taking place.
At Hopkins, Professor Neil
Cohen, of the Psychology
Department, is just beginning
to work with Benjamin, so as to
analyze in detail the components of his skilled "performance." While some people
may think that Benjamin has
just memorized relationships
between numbers, he has just
"upped-the-speed" of mathmanipulation
ematical
the real situation is a combination of both these ideas and
more. Experts in any field will
have a knowledge of the facts
in the field that surpasses nearly everyone. Experts in a field
may be able to gain access to
that information faster. If they
gain access to information and
then process it more efficiently, it is because they know better strategies, methods that

Art Benjamin, a Hopkins Graduate Student. Benjamin's calculating
talents are so unusual that they have warranted careful study.

have fewer intermediate steps,
and are able to deal with the information faster. Each of these
improvements in efficiency of
manipulations has its outward
manifestion being one of
relatively great speed or skill.
The performance of excellent
manipulation processes, such as
those of Benjamin, are extraordinary, but what can they do
for other persons? Most individuals have a "normal" level
of ability, and still others have
severely limited levels of ability. Perhaps if the processes in
different levels of skill can be
broken down into discrete
steps, these steps can be used to
help those in need of enhancement of their skills.
Art Benjamin revealed that
in order to get the most out of
his mathematical skills he uses
several techniques to "stretch"
them. The first difference in his
method of manipulating
numbers is that he works from
left to right. For example, when
multiplying 121 times 3, he will
take 120 times 3 and then add
it to 1 times 3 to obtain 363. To
help remember three digit
numbers he uses a type of

phonetic code whereby a
number is associated with a letter and then combined with
other associated letters to form
a word (sometimes a new word
with a bizarre spelling). He
sometimes has difficulty
remembering the value of a
"hundreds column" in a
number he is manipulating. The
method he uses is not that
unusual—he discretely uses his
fingers to record a number. To
manipulate numbers, Benjamin
says he does not "see" the actual
numbers in his head. Instead he
silently "verbalizes" them in
his mind and works with them
in that method. In the processing of very large numbers, he
sometimes works from the
center of the number outwards.
He also sometimes works
with numbers close to the
numbers he really wants the
answer of, and the compensates for differences in the
values. Perhaps if all of these
methods are old hat to you, you
may get to be part of some
researcher's experiment and get
to compare methods with Art
Benjamin.

All and all it was a neat little

wanted to highlight his annual

coach Jerry Pfiefer needed to
.spark his club for the upcoming final stretch and it was just

build some confidence.
The Blue Jay football team is
now 4-2 and these next three

from another mediocre one.
After a good start, a mediocre
season will undoubtedly be a
big disappointment.
The Jays did what they were
supposed to do to Georgetown.

be the case in the first quarter.
On its opening possession,
Georgetown came out swinging
and Hopkins didn't answer the
bell. The Hoyas went 88 yards
on 13 plays, all but one were on
the ground, to take a 7-0 lead.
The Blue Jay defense couldn't
contain the option and
Georgetown ran the ball into
the end zone.
"That first series, we played
in slow motion," said defensive
coordinator Bob Babb. "We
didn't react quickly enough."

to move the ball on its opening
series and punted it back to the
Hoyas. On their sixth play of
the drive, Georgetown made its
first mistake of the game. Steve
Paradakis recovered a fumble
on the Hoya's 35-yard line.

went 35 yards in ten plays for
a touchdown. Mark Campbell
hit Brendan Courtney on an up

After the tourney victors
were established, the coaches
set out to decide upon the
traveling All-Star teams.
Savoye, Fatula, Kenoian,
Seydel, Collins, White, Klink,
and Perlinn all went to trials,
where the selectors got the opportunity to look at all the
players who were trying out for
the squads. This number was
then cut down in half so that
the coaches could get a better
look at those they felt were
more talented. Savoye, Fatula,
Kenoian, Seydel, and White all
made it to this second level.
After another round of trials,
the two All-Star teams were announced, with Savoye, Fatula,
and Seydel all being named to
the first team while White was
named to the second. Kenoian
was unbelieveably passed over.
Despite this grave oversight,
Hopkins ended up wellrepresented.
The Baltimore College Tournament Championship was a
superb way to end a fair season.
Their tournament record was
four wins, one tie, and no
losses. As Coach Anderson
claimed, "We are definitely a
tournament team."
The final regular season
record was six wins, seven
losses, and two ties. Their last
game against MAC rival
Haverford ended in a 2-1 loss.
Hopkins got on the board first
as Patti Ordonez continued her

hot streak, scoring in the first
half. It was her fourth goal in
the past four games. The Lady
Jays, however, were doomed by
the referees, who called an extremely unfair game. Haverford came back and scored two
goals on the frustrated Jays.
Coaches Sally Beth Anderson and Jeanette DeVos and
their hocksters are already

looking forward to having a
much improved 1986 season.
The squad is losing only two
seniors, goalie Amy Zimmerman and forward Grace Tung.
Besides returning many very
talented players, Hopkins
hopes to benefit from next
year's freshmen, just as it did
this year.

team raced against Haverford
and Coppin St. last Saturday
afternoon at Homewood. The
Jays routed Coppin State, but

dominance of the MAC as he
won again, despite the fact that
some Haverford racers obviously went to the Rosie Ruiz
school of distance running.

not disqualified, but Raiser
managed to win by a good 50
seconds anyway.

deserved week off from competition. They take their 9-1
record up to Franklin and Marshall tomorrow afternoon
where they will have their final
dual meet of the season.

Registrar's New Report Finds
Enrollment on the Upswing
by Jeff Horn
The Hopkins community is
growing and changing according to the results of a recent
registrar's report which
documents 1985 fall term
enrollment.
The report shows that the
Homewood campus' enrollment has grown from 1,812
undergraduates in the School of
Arts and Sciences in 1984 to
1,861 in 1985. The G.W.C.
Whiting School of Engineering
has also grown from 566
undergruaduates last year to
604 this year.
The rest of the Hopkins community however, is stagnant
relative to Homewood—with
the only growth outside Homewood coming from the admission of more special students
and the addition of the nursing
program.

The Hopkins community totals 11,656 students this year as
opposed to 11,136 last year.
This total includes Homewood,
the Medical School, Public
Health, Nursing, The School of
Advanced International Studies
(SAIS) in Washington D.C.,
SAIS' campus in Bologna, Italy, and the Peabody Conservatory.
The enrollment at the
Homewood campus is 9,066,
up from 8,628 last year. The increase comes from many more
part-time graduate students in
more
and
engineering
undergrad special students in
the School of Continuing
Studies.
There are 2,660 full time
undergraduates and graduates
in the School of Arts and
Sciences, 856 full-time
engineering undergraduates and
graduates, 2,287 part-time

engineering undergraduates and
graduates and 3,263 undergraduates and graduates in the
School of Continuing Studies.
The other reports from the
registrar show the other
changes in the demographics of
the Homewood campus, like
sex, major, and hometown.
Women, for example, are 34.2
percent of all undergraduates.
In Arts and Sciences, women
are 38.3 percent of the undergraduates, as compared to only 21.1 percent in Engineering.
The report also broke down
enrollment by major at
Homewood. Natural Science
Majors (all sciences) constitute
34.1 percent with biology,
chemistry, and natural science
area majors or declared premeds making up 27.2 percent of
the undergraduates.

All Factions Pleased With
Task Force's Park Report
Continued from Page 1

presented to the press by David
S. Cordish, the lawyer who
headed the task force. "By consensus, the park will remain a
park," he explained, "Yet part
of Wyman will be made
available to the University on a
lease basis for use by intramural
athletics."
This, in turn, would allow
the university-owned BIA field,
which is currently located in a
ravine on the western side of
San Martin Drive, to be used as
a development site for further
expansion. Hopkins would then
be permitted to lease the section
of Wyman Park known as
"The Meadow" to use as the
new intramural field.
"The concept of putting the
intramural field in the park is
enthusiastically supported by
the entire task force, including
neighborhood leaders, city
liasons, and Hopkins," stated
Cordish. "The task force had
to assimilate different needs, all
of which were very legitimate
and very understandable.
"The park is a wonderful
treasure. We feel that if it could
possibly be preserved, that
would be a tremendous plus,"
Cordish continued. "But allowing Hopkins to expand would
also be of tremendous social
good. The solution was a
natural outcome [which was]
the result of the hearings and
testimonies we had."
Ross Jones, university vicepresident and secretary, and
representative on the task force
stated that the school wholeheartedly endorses the plan.
"This proposal accomplishes
three things: It gives Hopkins
more
opportunity
to
develop.. .grants us the oppor-

tunity to acquire much needed
space, and allows the community to preserve open vistas,"
summarized Jones.
Dagman Miller, chairperson
of the Commitee United to
Save Wyman Park, said she
was "optimistic and thankful"
and looked upon the proposal
with "much enthusiasm.""We
as neighbors were reacting to
something we felt strongly
about," she said. "Our park is
precious." Miller expressed her
satisfaction at being "part of
the process" in determining the
park's fate and looked forward
to "continued efforts to save
parkland."
Mayor Shaefer was extremely pleased with the interim
report findings and recommendation. "I knew what the
answer would be—there would
be no compromise of the city's
parkland. The proposal is a
wonderful concept," he said.
Schaefer commended all involved for "their leadership"
and was amazed at the level of
cooperation that led to the
resolution. "The amount of erroneous information out there
this summer was amazing to
me. Now Hopkins and the
community are talking and
that's how the situation got
worked out. I just can't get
over my admiration."
Schaefer strongly defended
the solution recommended by
the task force after it was
criticized as only "a stopgap"
which did not consider the
long-term problem. The future
need for university expansion
will have to be dealt with as it
arises in the future, explained
the mayor. He also argued that
the great aspect of the present
proposal is that its acceptable
by everyone.

"Not only does it preserve
the park but it generates jobs
that are very important," he explained."We have to realize the
importance of the relationship
of a university and its
community."
The mayor formed the task
last summer in response to outcries not only from community resdents, but from individuals from all over
Maryland and the nation. Concerns about saving parkland
came from as far away as
California according to the
thayor.
"Parks belong to everyone,"
said the mayor. "There's a lot
of work still to do, but to me,
[the major conflict] is solved.
The details of the recommendation are yet to be worked out.
The problem of exactly where
and how much acerage would
become available to Hopkins
must still be decided. The
technical aspects of the lease
agreement will also have to be
discussed, as well as the question of who will be responsible
to maintain the parkland.
Cordish did make it clear,
however, that only the land the
University requires for the
athletic field will be leased. The
area will not be cleared but instead is to be used in its current
state. Residents feel that this
agreement will not cause any
problems since many students
and student groups already use
the park for athletic purposes.
The task force is scheduled to
present its final report to the
mayor on December 1.
Although the final decision
rests with the Parks Board, the
unanimous support of the proposal by the mayor and the task
force should guarantee its
approval.

campus.

Shade said,"We don't want to
get stuck to a specific schedule,
but a student won't have to
wait more than fifteen minutes
to catch a ride up."
The new "McShuttle" is
sponsored jointly by the Student Services Committee and
the Office of Student Activities.

The fifth annual Phi Psi 500
was held throughout the afternoon of Saturday, October 26,
on the Gilman Quad. The Phi
Psi 500 is a competition sponsored each year by the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity with the proceeds from entry fees going
directly to Santa Claus
Anonymous, a Baltimore charity which to help area needy
around Christmas time.
The winning teams in the
competition were the Pink
Flamingos, HYC, Radioactive
Bat Jiz, Beasts of Baker,
Drunk, and Slick and His
Heads. Kegs were awarded to
the Alpha Phi and Phi Mu
Sororities, Phi Kappa Psi Little Sisters, and the Pi Lambda
Phi fraternity. Phi Kappa Psi
collected close to 1200 dollars
for Santa Claus Anonymous. A
total of 225 students participated in the games.
In the past, the Phi Psi 500

race had been a 1.5-mile run
and beer drinking contest, but
the fraternity had to change to
the present format last year, in
view of the revised administration policy on student drinking
on campus and at university
events.
This year's competition was
organized by race chairmen
Srikar Reddy and Sanjiv Patel.
Students formed teams of
five people and, for a four
dollar donation per participant,
they were permitted, even encouraged, to compete in a
variety of challenging events.
Dinners at Armand's Pizzeria
were presented to the top six
teams, kegs were awarded, and
all participants recieved Phi Psi
500 T-Shirts, free sodas, and invitations to the "500 Party" at
the fraternity house Saturday
night. A disc jockey was on
hand to play records during the
games, and a local radio station
gave out free prizes.

The Henry Luce Foundation
annually selects 15 Luce
Scholars from a variety of
backgrounds to spend a year
in the Far East. The program
built around individual internships and work/study arrangements developed by
representatives of the Asia
Foundation and based on the
student's career interest and
preparation. The scholarship
award includes a substantial
stipend plus a family and
transportation allowance.
Rather than offer training
for future Asian specialists, this
program concentrates exclusively on providing an intensive experience in Asia to
young Americans from other
fields who would not otherwise expect to have such an
opportunity during the normal course of their career.
This program involves no
academic credit, and the participants normally do not
enroll in academic institutions. Luce Scholars have interned in the past with an architectural firm in Tokyo, a
forestry project in Indonesia,
a training facility for public
administration in Malaysia, a
master gardener in Kyoto, a
community medicine project

year for which they are applying. Candidates may not

nominees of all participating
colleges and universities, the
Foundation
Churchill

academic
outstanding
achievement, scores on the
Graduate Record Examination, demonstrated concern
for critical problems of society, and capacity for original
and creative work. Applicants must take both the
Aptitude and the Advance
Tests on or before the October GRE test date and have
the scores sent directly to the
Churchill Foundation.

realize how important knowing

Is Everybody Happy?
If journalists are, as somebody once
said, professional complainers, then the
Wyman Park deal announced this week
is a journalist's nightmare. Nobody
seems to be upset.
We have to admit that's actually a
good thing, of course. The mayor's task
force, composed of university representatives and community members, has apparently found a fair and reasonable
solution that everyone can live with.
Although the details are still undecided, the basic idea is that the university
will lease part of the park to use as an
intramural field, allowing it to build on
the current intramural field, which the
university owns. (The part of the park
to be leased is near the intersection of
Tudor Arms Avenue and University
Parkway.)
Since an athletic field will disrupt the
park far less than a new research
building, the save-the-park forces are
happy. Since Hopkins will have far more
land to build on than it previously did,
the university is happy.
In the midst of all the celebrating,
however, it ought to be remembered—

as we noted a few weeks ago—that the
whole fuss really need never have arisen.
Somebody within the university could
certainly have thought of a solution like
this one before the school tried to take
over the park in the first place. Instead,
the university tried to grab the land during the summer (which looked sneaky),
and the university's relationship with the
community—which has never been very
good—worsened considerably.
When the brouhaha reached its
zenith—and when both sides began looking to him for support—the mayor
organized the task force which has just
recommended the compromise described above. And while both sides actually
involved in the dispute seem to be fairly
happy, it is the mayor, of course, who
comes off smelling the most like a rose.
The university can hardly be said to
have won this one. It got into an unnecessary squabble with a community
that already didn't like it very much. But
neither did it lose, and maybe, considering the way the whole affair began, that
was the best that could be expected.

Thank you for your feedback.
I hope my answers help. But if
they don't, remember I'm not
legally liable. So that others can
benefit, here are the letters.

such bigotry, especially when

To the Editor:
Frank Caprio
I respect good comedy and
good jokes and like to think
that I can take them in stride
But I do not find Sujata Banarjee's "Where the Boys Are:
Searching for Waves at JHU"
to be good comedy or even to
contain good jokes. In fact, I
found the article to be degrading, humiliating, and offensive.
I found particularly offensive
the part on New Jersey. Being
a resident of N.J. has nothing
to do with this at all. . .well
maybe not, but it makes no
difference.
Miss Banerjee jests about
there existing Bar Mitzvahs in
N.J. Although I am not an expert on Jewish affairs, I am not
naive, simple-minded or insipient enough to think that Bar
Mitzvahs do not exist outside of
N.J. I also fail to see what is so
wrong about the existence of
Bar Mitzvahs. I hope that Miss
Banerjee will explain this to me
at the next Jewish Association
meeting.
I have never made any pretenses that I come from New
York, and I do not think that
I have a nasal-pitched accent.
Therefore these two statements
about all N.J. JHU students are
lies.
I would like to commend
Miss Banerjee on writing an offensive and misleading article
and would hope that she finds
it in her heart not to continue
these types of jests.
Ty Hyderally

while trying to undo the
damage that has been done to
minorities, innocent members
of the "majority" will be hurt.
Because she wants society to
practice more humanitarian
values, Scogna supports a hiring practice which is as damaging and morally repugnant as
that to which she is opposed.
Minority members may now
be getting jobs which they
would not have gotten before,
but they are not learning the
skills necessary for obtaining
and keeping these jobs should
affirmative action be repealed.
Employers, meanwhile, are
forced to maintain quotas, a
practice which limits their ability to hire the best applicants
and inevitably results in a less
productive society. Finally, affirmative action is, by definition, discriminatory. The focus
of discrimination has merely
been shifted.
Given these detriments, it is
hard to understand why
anyone, especially someone
who espouses humanitarianism, can advocate affirmative
action. The only hiring practice
which is morally defensible is
one which is based solely on
merit.
Debra Hamel

Looking at the Sky
To the Editor:
I would like to thank Donna
Peremes for giving me this
chance to further lash out at her
and all of the other members of
the Feminist Alliance who objected to the "advice" I gave in

my book review of Dr. Fegg's
Encyclopaedia of All World
Knowledge. My response will
be two-fold. The first as
generic, cliche and technical as
the Peremes letter, and the second completely different.
Now, the generic one. Leaving aside the inherent hypocrisy
of "resenting advice" and the
inanity of voicing "objections
[which] are fairly apparent,"
the first question I would like
to address is whether a comparison of the Feminist Alliance
and the American Nazi Party is
patently absurd."
It would depend on the nature of the comparison, would
it not? If they are grouped
together under the heading
"organizations" clearly it is not
absurd, whereas under the
heading "White Supremacy
Groups" it would be. The
heading used was "extremist
group," and "extremist being
a subjective appraisal which to
me means advocating an act
which / believe to be ludicrous,
I am perfectly within my right
to compare these two groups.
This is because I believe both
extermination of Jews and
TEP-newsletter banning to be
ludicrous. If the Alliance is insulted, good—perhaps it will
make them rethink their past
actions. I must stress that I
mean no insult to females as a
whole, just as I mean no insult
to whites as a whole (indeed,
some of my best friends are
white and/or female).
Now the humour issue—Peremes comes so close when she
points out that Pythons'
remarks are "many times...a
mockery." They never mean to
insult, if they do, it's because
you choose to be insulted, and
is that any fault of theirs, much
less grounds for censorship?
Of course there is blatant
misogyny and racism in our
society, but not in Python.
Python is art, and art has no
room for malice. Art is presented to be interpreted, and that
interpretation should be left to
the interpreter—not to myself,
the Feminist Alliance, or any

third party.
Indeed, I am not advocating
that we "park our brains outside the theater door," but I am
advocating taking our brains
out of reverse and realizing that
interpretation of art has no
ablsoute truth, and so a critique
should be taken for what it is—
a subjective statement of one
person's truth, in this case my
truth, which is that ragging on
feminists is funny. This is no
more or less true than Peremes's
assertion that it is not—but
neither of us has a right to force
our opinions on any third party, which is what Peremes and
the truly malicious misogynist
such as the rapist both do.
Why then, do I critique and
give advice? Simple, it's fun,
and I get free books. Anyone is
free to throw my opinions
away. No one is free to cross
Peremes's own "line" between
humour and sexism. Take your
pick of critics.
And now for something completely different: Listen, Donna, yeah, you were supposed to
"chuckle it off." If more people were less uptight and just
took the time to relax, look at
the sky and love each other,
there would be no reason for
any of these bad feelings. I love
you, Donna. So do my roommates (and the Black & Blue
Jay). Let's get together and
look at the sky sometime.
Amitava 7 Biswas A.O.

Affirmative Action II
To the Editor:
Kathleen Scogna's letter (October 18) was based on one
good idea. Jobs should be
awarded on productive ability
and passed performance not on
gender. Rational people would
judge a person on these two
criteria and expect to be judged similarly. Kathleen is angry
(justifiably so) because as she
claims these factors were not
used in the past to decide who
got a job. She says that an ad-

ministrative directive(program)
is needed to correct these past
injustices.
The program would equalize
the ratio between male and female employees at the University. The question to be asked
is "At whose expense will this
equalization be achieved?"
(Hint: think tuition.) I do not
expect the school to fire enough
male employees to achieve this
ratio. Another alternative is hiring enough women so that this
ratio is achieved right away.
Who would pay for these extra
employees?
The only "reasonable" solution is to make sure the next
people that Johns Hopkins
hires are female. Is Kathleen
asking that a job qualification
be based on gender? Isn't that
the injustice responsible for this
mess? Do not tell me that this
new injustice would correct a
past wrong. I know two wrongs
do not make a right.
The most evil part of her letter can be found in the last
paragraph. I quote,"She has to
prove herself better than all the
men competing for the same
job. Chen apparently sees
nothing wrong with this. I certainly do." Kathleen thinks it is
wrong for the University to
choose the person who is better
qualified for a job. Would
anyone have Hopkins hire the
person that is not the best for
the job? Would she still object
to that quote if two words were
added so it reads as follows?
"She has to prove herself better than all the men and women
competing for the same job."
I'm paying this University and
I expect the administration to
hire the best qualified person
for the job. Not the best qualified person of any one pressure
group. Any policy that forces
the administration to settle for
second best is wrong. I hope
Hopkins continues awarding
jobs to people who deserve
them because they worked hard
and can prove they are the best
qualified.
Jordan Levy

Let's All Go to the H.O.P.
by Kathleen McCarthy
The
HOP
(Hopkins
Organization for Programming), which was created last
year as a standing committee of
the Student Council in order to
coordinate social programming
on campus, acquired a new
director last month,junior Andrew Chun, in the wake of
Kristen Noyes's resignation
from the post. I spoke with Andrew Chun about the HOP
itself; its purpose and his plans
for the present school year.
The HOP, perhaps in no
small amount due to its relative
newness and to its unique and
somewhat misleading acronym,
generates questions from the
student body as to its actual
purpose: "Basically the HOP is
an expansion of the old social
committee of the Student Council," explains Chun. It is a
revamped social committee
with significant authority and
was formed primarily with the
idealistic purpose of hoping to
offset the impact of a "dry
campus" on Student Council
sponsored events. The advent
of a dry campus was recognized by both administrators and
students alike as having a
significant effect on the attendance of and enjoyment of
these events. "The administration and students involved,
wanted to create a new social
entity," continued Chun,
"which was primarily concerned with planning—you don't
want three big social events on
one weekend and none on the
next—and upgrading the level
of entertainment. We can no
longer get a DJ and throw
things together and call it a
dance and expect it to be successful...we have to make it a

situation where the person is
coming for the entertainment,
for the social thing we can offer you." A new organization
was called for. What Johns
Hopkins needed, apparently,
was a controlling body, with
authority, that could efficiently channel and direct social
energy into actual events. That
met need is the essence of the
HOP's existence.
Andrew Chun, as director of
that social entity, has a great
deal of responsibility. Chun
took over the position temporarily in late September, as
the executive members of the
Student Council searched for a
new director. Chun was soon
after installed officially as it
became evident that his
capabilities, zeal and previous
social committee experience
more than qualified him for the
position. Andrew Chun presides over the Executive Board
of the HOP, which consists of
representatives from the
various groups that plan social
events, i.e., The Office of
Residential Life, IFC, the Student Council, etc. The HOP
itself is further broken down into committees, in which the actual work is done: the social
committee, which plans social
events such as dances and parties; the Fine Arts Committee,
which sponsors such things as
trips to museums and plays; the
Union Board, which basically
handles any social event not
falling under the above
categories; and finally, the
Publicity Committee.
Chun sees his position as
primarily that of a coordinator,
who delegates authority, organizes the various groups and
manages the budget. He hopes

to see the position of director
evolve to this overseer role from
the role of active participant in
all the subcommittees, which
characterized the position in its
initial year. "The committees,
once started, know what to
do...my job is to approve
what they do because I'm in
touch with what everyone else
is doing. Cooperation is the
biggest thing, to get as many
groups as possible involved in
the programs...it's for the
school," says Chun.
So far the efforts of the HOP
have been encouraging. In particular, events sponsored by the
Fine Arts committee, such as
the recent A Night at the Iguana
trip, which was sold out.
The HOP is planning a big
dance on November 8 in the
Glass
Pavilion.
Chun
is
also
working
on
instituting a schoolwide semiformal in the spring. Other projects in the works are the continuation of the Comedy Clubs,
started last year, and the initiation of Coffeehouses, which
will provide a club atmosphere

Friday and Saturday night: A

The B.S.U.'s production of
A Raisin in the Sun was also a
production with somewhat

ragged edges, but here as well
that helped to foster a more

cast members played it with a

the feeling that a professional

result would have made it far
too oppressive. The Parent's
Weekend production was

A quick run-down of the
essentials: The play is about a
black family living in Chicago
during the fifties. Three generations live in one apartment—
Mama (Oneeka Williams), her
35-year-old son Walter Lee
(Julian Procope), his wife Ruth
(Jacqueline Wilson), their son
Travis (Darrell Frazier), and
Walter's sister Beneatha
(Emelia Duaway). Mama receives $10,000 from her late
husband's insurance policy.
With $3500 of it she puts a
down-payment on a house that
happens to be in a white
neighborhood. The rest she
gives to Walter Lee to open a
liquor store with the condition
that he save some for
Beneatha's college education.
One of Walter's business partners runs off with all the
money. Walter then decides to
take the bribe the white
neighborhood committee has
offered them if they don't move
into the house, but he re-

discovers his manhood and his

present (Jim Sullivan) and his

The play was rather well
done, with uniformly good acting throughout. Especially
good were Jacqueline Wilson
and Oneeka Williams. Certain
scenes were very powerful. For
example, the scene in which
Ruth has to tell Walter she's
pregnant and has put down
money for an abortion.
If there was a problem with
the whole production (at least
Saturday night) it was the
mystifying audience reaction—
they seemed to think the play
was a comedy. For example,
when Mama learns Walter has
lost all the money, she loses
control and starts hitting him.
The people sitting in back of me
thought it was the funniest
thing in the world. I personally
think the cast pulled the powerful scenes off—but even during
the last scene when Walter is
struggling to hold back his
tears, telling his family how
proud he is, people in the audience were still laughing at
Darrell Frazier's imitation of a
little kid. I don't know. It may
be that in the 25 years or so
since this play was written, the
issues have gotten so cliched
that no one can take them with
complete seriousness.
Saturday night: Coffee House
in the Great Hall
I must admit that I wasn't at
the Coffee House long enough
to see all the acts but I think I
was there long enough to get a
feel for what was going on.
Unlike past coffee houses
where there has always been a
paid (semi-) professional band
or entertainer, last Saturday
night all the entertainment was
supplied by students. There
were seven acts in all, ranging
from a clarinet-flute duet to a
mime and juggling act.
This event, even more than
the other two, symbolizes what
I meant about rough edges.
None of the performances I saw
was extremely polished or
perfected—this was no talent
show—and that's good. You
don't come into the place with
great expectations all ready to
judge what's going to be put in
front of you. You marvel instead at moments which transcend the amateurish such as
singer-guitarist Jay Harris hitting an unwavering high note or
stand-up comedian Loren Fox
telling a genuinely funny joke.
That's not to say that the artists in general last weekend
weren't talented—it's just a different kind of talent—a talent
born not of polished genius but
of pleasure in performing. No
one forced anyone to play in
the Hopkins Band; no one forced anyone to act in A Raisin in
the Sun; no one forced anyone
to perform at the Coffee
House—they did what they did
because they enjoyed it. At
Hopkins, this land of work-aholics and over-achievers, that
attitude, displayed last
weekend, was unbelieveably
refreshing.
