The Sailor's Edge:A Photographic Masterpiece
by Andy Gray
The Sailor's Edge.
by Daniel Forster. Holt,
Rinehart and Winston, $35.00
to 12/31, $50.00 thereafter.
Contrary to common belief,
watching sailboats race is not
about as exciting as watching
the grass grow. One look at The
Sailor's Edge, a collection of
marine photographs by Daniel
Forster (with text by Jay
Broze), should convince even
the most cynical that there is
much more to sailing than
wearing topsiders while drinking a seabreeze at the Bar Harbour Yacht Club. The book is
a delight for world class sailor
and land-lubber alike.
The book is comprised of
four chapters, each dealing with
a specific genre of sailing. Each
chapter has a short (3 pgs.) introduction written by Broze
which informs the reader of
just what and at whom he is
looking at. These introductions
also provide a little insight into
the history and lore of these
various aspects of sailing. To
those familiar to the world of
sailing, these introductions
serve little more than to refresh
the memory. However, to the
uninitiated, they do provide
enough information to bring a
little drama to the photograph,
especially in the chapter which
deals with the Olympics.
The first chapter is entitled
"Acrobatic," as one might
guess, it deals with windsurfing,
with special attention paid to
wave-jumping. This is without
a clout:4 the most exciting part
of the book; windsurfing,
especially wave-jumping, is at
the very cutting edge of sailing
technology. The pictures are
quite powerful and visually

vibrant, expressing a wide
variety of emotions. There are
stark photographs where the
subject is not so much the windsurfer, but really the surrounding. These photos truly give the
impression of man working his
board to master the elements,
a pursuit that is both lonely and
exuberant. There are also those
pictures which are aweinspiring in the excitement and
motion that they express. These
are images that do not merely
impress; they tantalize. Upon
each viewing of this section, 1
fantasize of dropping the
books, and taking a short
board out to Kaui, or some
other land blessed with waves,
and mastering this beautiful
form of flying.
chapter,
second
The
"Athletics," deals with the
Olympics classes. Since there
are seven Olympic classes, each
form is given only a cursory
review. This is not to say that
this section was poorly done,
though. Many of the
photographs are excellent,
especially those of the Tornadoes (19 foot catamarans),
which give a marvelous impression of speed and elan. For
those in the Hopkins Sailing
Club, special attention should
be paid to the 470 section
(Hopkins owns six of these
high performance dinghies).
"Powerful," the third
chapter, focuses on the ocean
racing circuit. The photos range
from fleet pictures, which gives
the reader some idea of the immense competition, to detailed
close-ups, hectic moments of
teamwork that the rigors of
ocean racing require. There is
one fantastic sequence of
photos of the yacht Formidable
experiencing a knock-down

broach (that's big-boat talk for
tipping over, a somewhat hairy
exercise in a forty-foot yacht).
Again, the theme of man battling nature re-appears, and in
many of the photos the envious
could easily be the subject.
Maxi-boats and Twelve
Meters are the subject of the
final chapter, "Prestigious."
Maxi-boats (referring to their
racing rating, i.e. maximum
rating) are the penultimate
ocean racers, often reaching
over 80 feet in length. These
boats truly dwarf their crews,
which often number over 20
members. One step above the
maxis on the prestige scale are
the Twelve Meters. These
thoroughbreeds of the yachting
world have been exclusively used,
until recently, for America's
Cup competition. This section
is nicely executed, conferring
well a sense of the immense
power and forces that these
yachts are able to generate.
There is also a small section on
the 128 foot J-Class yacht
Velsheda. The J-Class boats
were the predecessors of the
Twelve Meters in America's
Cup competition. Velsheda is
the only surviving example of
this class that flourished in the
1930's and then quickly died
out with the advent of World
War II.
There is a small section at the
end of the book which deals
with the 1987 America's Cup,
to be held in Perth, Australia.
There are no revelations here,
the thrust being that the Twelve
Meter class, especially with its
new world champion ship, is an
extremely active class. Perth
promises to hold a great deal of
racing excitement. There is also
a section in which world-class
sailors (Bobby Naish, Dennis

Conner, Gary Jobson, and
Cino Ricci) pay homage to the
photographic genius of Daniel
Forster; high praise indeed,
coming from such revered
sailors. There is also a black
and white index of photos,
which provides interesting in-,
formation on each picture.
This is a marvelous book;
however, genius has its cost. In
this case, is is $35.00, and it will
go up to $50.00 by the end of
the year. If you are a sailing

fanatic, this book is a "mustbuy;" remember, though, that
it is a coffee table book, and is
best appreciated when shared
with friends. For many, the
price is too steep, but for those
who appreciate excellent
photography of some of the
world's most beautiful boats,

CHINESE DEMOCRACY
An investigation into the nature and
meaning of "democracy" in China today
With a report on the remarkable
but short-lived Democracy Movement

by Andrew J. Nathan

_by Howell Sasser
Chinese Democracy
by Andrew J. Nathan, Borzoi
Books, $22.95. 255 pages.
To document the history of
as broad a concept as democracy
in any nation would seem to be
a task worthy either of a
lifetime of study or of a junior
high school civics paper. It is
impossible, one would reason,
to seriously address such a subject without falling prey to
either excessive detail or excessive simplification. Chinese
Democracy manages to avoid
these traps and conveys author
Andrew J. Nathan's understanding of the subject without
useless esoterica.
Active democratic thought in
China dates only from the late
nineteenth century and dates its
birth to the demonstrations
staged by holders of official
scholarship degrees, against the
terms of the 1895 SinoJapanese peace treaty. The
scholars invoked the ancient
right of remonstrance(personal
opinions submitted to the
emperor through channels)
conferred upon the learned.

Out of these protests grew
"study societies" and political
journals circulated as private
correspondence.
These outlets of ideas were
also employed by the factions
of the so-called Democratic
Movement in the late 1970's.
Mimeographed periodicals appeared at the same time as the
"Democracy Wall," publicized
in the Western media. The factions were allowed relative
freedom of speech in as much
as none criticized the basis of
the state or the place of the
Communist Party within the
state.
These restrictions lead to a
discussion of the origins and
bases of the Chinese notion of
democracy. One of the leaders
of the nineteenth century
scholars' movement, the
political scientist Liang
Quichao, wrote that democracy
was the harmony of wills of the
individual and the state. He left
no room for possible disagreement between the tw3, and consequently, no mechanism for
dealing with dissent(other than
punitive action) was included in
any of the "democratic" con-

This is not just
another dry slog
through a dry
topic....
stitutions of the People's
Republic.
Chinese Democracy treats its
subject matter thoroughly, if
not impartially. Nathan is
openly sympathetic to the
Democratic Movement without
treating the government with
undue harshness. His extensive
use of sources and contacts
within China precludes the
sugesstion that he is a foreigner
writing solely from a
foreigner's perspective.
This is not just another dry
slog through a dry topic.
Beyond its imposing title,
Chinese Democracy presents a
lively picture of Chinese
political life and culture. It is
not just for students of political
science, but is also worthwhile
for anyone with an interest in
the world's most populous
country.

Science
Hopkins Grad Student Astounds and Amazes
The Mental Feats ofthis "Calculating Prodigy"are Studied
by Edmund Meade
The book is The Great Mental
Calculators—Past and Present
by Steven Smith. The person is
Arthur Benjamin, a graduate
student in the mathematical
sciences department here at
Johns Hopkins. Benjamin is
the only living American whose
biography is in The Great Mental Calculators. Benjamin is not
a mathematical prodigy, but he
can multiply two three-digit
numbers together faster than an
electronic hand-held calculator.
He can even "square" a four
digit number faster than a
calculator. Numbers with a
greater number of digits take
him more time than a calculator. But he can still compute, in
his head, the value of 1521 x
7056(which equals 10,732,176)
in a matter of about 1 minute.
Right now he can comfortably
handle the "squaring" of fivedigit numbers (such as 27,354).
A worst-case scenario is the
multiplication of two different
six digit numbers by each other.
That problem will take him
several minutes.
Art Benjamin's talent puts
him into some pretty exclusive
company. He may not be a
math prodigy, but he is a
"calculating prodigy." He can
multiply, divide, square, and
find the roots of fairly large
numbers. Another calculating
prodigy that Benjamin has met,
in Amsterdam, was competely
obsessed with numbers. Benjamin, however, is interested in a
number of other things. He is
presently studying integer pro-

gramming, a facet of operations research, and discrete
mathematics.
Art Benjamin was an applied
mathematics major as an
undergraduate at CarnegieMellon University in Pittsburgh. He came to Hopkins
looking for a department that
had a fairly theoretical approach to the solution of problems in applied mathematics.
Benjamin is studying these
theoretical aspects to solve real
applied math problems.
Part of Benjamin's motivation
for practicing and reinforcing his
strength in manipulating
numbers came from his nightclub act where he performed his
math wizardry and some
displays of prestidigitation.
These and other instances in
which he interacted with the
public encouraged him to spend
the time necessary to gain great
proficiency. Thus he sometimes
feels it to be a personal
challenge to see how far he can
de‘elop his talents. When Benjamin finds himself bored while
driving, he will multiply the
numbers on license plates
together.
The methods that Benjamin
uses to achieve his mathematical manipulation are intriguing
to those interested in determining how the mind handles such
processing. When Benjamin
was an undergraduate at
Carnegie-Mellon he was introduced to Dr. William Chase,
a professor of psychology. Professor Chase sought to produce
a better programming method
for computers and new ways to

teach math. Chase examined
how Benjamin performed his
"mental feats." A problem in
this analysis was that these feats
were often performed very
quickly (the square of a three
digit number takes about a second). Chase challenged him to
perform more difficult calculations. Benjamin had to practice
but he also had to develop the
confidence that he coud do difficult manipulations. The key is
that all these numbers must be
remembered and manipulated
in the short-term memory portion of the brain.
With the manipulation taking longer, Professor Chase
could ask Benjamin questions
so that he could glean information about some of the basic
problems taking place.
At Hopkins, Professor Neil
Cohen, of the Psychology
Department, is just beginning
to work with Benjamin, so as to
analyze in detail the components of his skilled "performance." While some people
may think that Benjamin has
just memorized relationships
between numbers, he has just
"upped-the-speed" of mathmanipulation
ematical
the real situation is a combination of both these ideas and
more. Experts in any field will
have a knowledge of the facts
in the field that surpasses nearly everyone. Experts in a field
may be able to gain access to
that information faster. If they
gain access to information and
then process it more efficiently, it is because they know better strategies, methods that

Art Benjamin, a Hopkins Graduate Student. Benjamin's calculating
talents are so unusual that they have warranted careful study.

have fewer intermediate steps,
and are able to deal with the information faster. Each of these
improvements in efficiency of
manipulations has its outward
manifestion being one of
relatively great speed or skill.
The performance of excellent
manipulation processes, such as
those of Benjamin, are extraordinary, but what can they do
for other persons? Most individuals have a "normal" level
of ability, and still others have
severely limited levels of ability. Perhaps if the processes in
different levels of skill can be
broken down into discrete
steps, these steps can be used to
help those in need of enhancement of their skills.
Art Benjamin revealed that
in order to get the most out of
his mathematical skills he uses
several techniques to "stretch"
them. The first difference in his
method of manipulating
numbers is that he works from
left to right. For example, when
multiplying 121 times 3, he will
take 120 times 3 and then add
it to 1 times 3 to obtain 363. To
help remember three digit
numbers he uses a type of

phonetic code whereby a
number is associated with a letter and then combined with
other associated letters to form
a word (sometimes a new word
with a bizarre spelling). He
sometimes has difficulty
remembering the value of a
"hundreds column" in a
number he is manipulating. The
method he uses is not that
unusual—he discretely uses his
fingers to record a number. To
manipulate numbers, Benjamin
says he does not "see" the actual
numbers in his head. Instead he
silently "verbalizes" them in
his mind and works with them
in that method. In the processing of very large numbers, he
sometimes works from the
center of the number outwards.
He also sometimes works
with numbers close to the
numbers he really wants the
answer of, and the compensates for differences in the
values. Perhaps if all of these
methods are old hat to you, you
may get to be part of some
researcher's experiment and get
to compare methods with Art
Benjamin.

All and all it was a neat little
win, that 27-7' 'victory over
Georgetown. It was just what
athletic director Bob Scott
wanted to highlight his annual
Bull Roast. It was just what
coach Jerry Pfiefer needed to
.spark his club for the upcoming final stretch and it was just
what the offense needed to
build some confidence.
The Blue Jay football team is
now 4-2 and these next three
games will decide a good season
from another mediocre one.
After a good start, a mediocre
season will undoubtedly be a
big disappointment.
The Jays did what they were
supposed to do to Georgetown.
They beat them badly. Only, it
did not appear as if that would
be the case in the first quarter.
On its opening possession,
Georgetown came out swinging
and Hopkins didn't answer the
bell. The Hoyas went 88 yards
on 13 plays, all but one were on
the ground, to take a 7-0 lead.
The Blue Jay defense couldn't
contain the option and
Georgetown ran the ball into
the end zone.
"That first series, we played
in slow motion," said defensive
coordinator Bob Babb. "We
didn't react quickly enough."
Trailing 7-0, Hopkins failed
to move the ball on its opening
series and punted it back to the
Hoyas. On their sixth play of
the drive, Georgetown made its
first mistake of the game. Steve
Paradakis recovered a fumble
on the Hoya's 35-yard line.
With first and ten in
Georgetown territory, Hopkins
went 35 yards in ten plays for
a touchdown. Mark Campbell
hit Brendan Courtney on an up

together, the tournament championship was, as Coach Sally
Beth Anderson put it, "a total
team effort."
After the tourney victors
were established, the coaches
set out to decide upon the
traveling All-Star teams.
Savoye, Fatula, Kenoian,
Seydel, Collins, White, Klink,
and Perlinn all went to trials,
where the selectors got the opportunity to look at all the
players who were trying out for
the squads. This number was
then cut down in half so that
the coaches could get a better
look at those they felt were
more talented. Savoye, Fatula,
Kenoian, Seydel, and White all
made it to this second level.
After another round of trials,
the two All-Star teams were announced, with Savoye, Fatula,
and Seydel all being named to
the first team while White was
named to the second. Kenoian
was unbelieveably passed over.
Despite this grave oversight,
Hopkins ended up wellrepresented.
The Baltimore College Tournament Championship was a
superb way to end a fair season.
Their tournament record was
four wins, one tie, and no
losses. As Coach Anderson
claimed, "We are definitely a
tournament team."
The final regular season
record was six wins, seven
losses, and two ties. Their last
game against MAC rival
Haverford ended in a 2-1 loss.
Hopkins got on the board first
as Patti Ordonez continued her

hot streak, scoring in the first
half. It was her fourth goal in
the past four games. The Lady
Jays, however, were doomed by
the referees, who called an extremely unfair game. Haverford came back and scored two
goals on the frustrated Jays.
Coaches Sally Beth Anderson and Jeanette DeVos and
their hocksters are already

looking forward to having a
much improved 1986 season.
The squad is losing only two
seniors, goalie Amy Zimmerman and forward Grace Tung.
Besides returning many very
talented players, Hopkins
hopes to benefit from next
year's freshmen, just as it did
this year.

Spikers End On Up Note
by Adam Warner
.The women's volleyball team
closed their season strongly,
taking three of five matches at
the Gallaudet Tournament to
grab fifth place.
It was a nice culmination to
a season marked by steady improvement under coach Dawn
Finnesy. Hopkins got off to a
slow start on the campaign, but
picked up a bit at the end and
finished with a record of 7-9.
Their mark in games was 20-19,
as most of their losses were
close, three game affairs.
The Jays opened the roundrobin tournament by dropping
a tough 15-8,14-16,15-4 decision to Eastern Mennonite. In
the second game of the match,
the Jays played perhaps their
best game of the tournament
considering that they were
against the wall.
In the dramatic win, they
were a perfect 24-24 in their
sets, and they hit 27 spikes successfully while missing but one.
Seven of the spikes went for
kills.
Senior captain Ilga Celmins
led the way once again with 14
sets and 8 spikes. Allison
Unger, a rapidly improving
freshman, had 10 sets for the
game, and a team high of 28 for
the match.
The Jays next faced Marymount, and disposed of them
easily by a 15-3,15-5 count.
This set up a big match with
Salisbury State to see who
would advance to the medal
round.

cher, a team that they squared
off against twice already in the
regular season. The squad's
split, then, but this time the
Jays prevailed decisively,
15-8,15-9.
In the first game, Ashi Rafi
paced the squad as she went on
a run of eight straight service
points. The sophomore helped
her own cause by contributing
a team high of ten successful
bumps, and two spikes.
Game 2 saw Celmins dominate once again. She hit all
twelve of her sets,and nailed
seven spikes, and a kill.
Hopkins was extended to
three games in their final
match, against Washington
College, but they held on to win
15-13,14-16,15-8.
All three games here were
hard fought contests that went
back and forth before one team
could emerge. It provided Celmins with an excellent opportunity to close out her career in
style, and she did just that. She
managed 31 spikes, and 50 sets
in the match, both team highs.
With Celmins as the lone
senior, Finessy has high hopes
for next season. The team still
has the status of a club, meaning volleyball is not considered
a varsity sport yet. This could
change though.
The coach is optimistic, saying that the team is "great to
work with, full of energy, and
willing to give 100 percent all of
the time. They're pressing on
for varsity status and they
deserve it because they're all
winners."
Junior Debbi Olson, who
figures to star again and lead
the squad next year, is also
quite encouraged by their progress. She feels that the Spikers
"played together as a team, and
everyone played well." One
problem she sees, though, is the
lack of publicity at the beginning of the season when the
squad is chosen. "There are a
lot of girls here who played in
high school, but didn't know
we had a team until it was too
late. We'll need to get to
freshmen earlier next year."

Harriers
The men's cross country
team raced against Haverford
and Coppin St. last Saturday
afternoon at Homewood. The
Jays routed Coppin State, but
fell to the Fords.
George Raiser continued his
dominance of the MAC as he
won again, despite the fact that
some Haverford racers obviously went to the Rosie Ruiz
school of distance running.
They cut the course and were
not disqualified, but Raiser
managed to win by a good 50
seconds anyway.
The women took a well
deserved week off from competition. They take their 9-1
record up to Franklin and Marshall tomorrow afternoon
where they will have their final
dual meet of the season.
